update.description:
![log_control.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3945315640-log_control.gif)

Differences from Gazebo classic:

* Seeking used to also update the iteration number. Now it resets iterations to zero.
* It's not possible to set `forward` for logs
* `LogPlaybackControl` and `WorldControl` messages work interchangeably. I'm considering adding a new message type, maybe `TimeControl`, which combines both, and deprecating the other 2.
* There's nothing preventing users from rewinding and seeking during regular simulation mode. I've added warnings to all the systems which I thought could be affected by jumps back in time. Jumping forward has no warning, and systems just treat it as a really large time step. The idea is that we can implement rewind and seek for these systems in the future, and we don't want to prevent users from supporting this on their systems.

## Command line

Try it out:

* While playing back a log (or not!), rewind:

`ign service -s /world/shapes/playback/control --reqtype ignition.msgs.LogPlaybackControl --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 5000 --req 'rewind: true'`

* Seek:

`ign service -s /world/shapes/playback/control --reqtype ignition.msgs.LogPlaybackControl --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean --timeout 5000 --req 'seek: {sec: 140}, pause: true'`


## Systems

Systems can detect rewinds by checking:

* `if (_info.simTime == std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())`
* `if (_info.dt < std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())`

To detect pause:

* `if (_info.paused)`

To detect time jump while paused (`dt` is zero during regular pause):

* `if (_info.paused && _info.dt != std::chrono::steady_clock::duration::zero())`

---

Needs [this ign-cmake PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/172/) to clear cppcheck.
update.title: Rewind / reset and seek

content.html: Thanks for looking into it!

content.raw:
I’ve been testing some changes in the [rewind\_seek\_playpause](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/branch/rewind_seek_playpause?dest=rewind_seek#diff) branch, and pipelines now pass twice in a row.

Looks like `control.rewind` could be used without being initialized
content.html:
I’ve been testing some changes in the rewind_seek_playpause branch, and pipelines now pass twice in a row.

Looks like control.rewind could be used without being initialized

content.raw: `INTEGRATION_play_pause` failed in the latest run. I can't reproduce it locally, but it looks like it tries to rewind the simulation when it shouldn't. Looking into it.
content.html: INTEGRATION_play_pause failed in the latest run. I can't reproduce it locally, but it looks like it tries to rewind the simulation when it shouldn't. Looking into it.

content.raw:
That seems to have been a spurious error? I can't reproduce it and it's no longer failing on pipelines.

In any case, while looking into that test I noticed another test was flaky for me locally, so I rearranged it a bit to see if it becomes more robust: 1ac6ca3

content.raw:
Nice I tested with subt and the levels seem to get loaded and unloaded fine.

I also tried inserting and removing objects using service calls but rewinding does not undo insertion / deletion. Maybe something for later.
content.html:
Nice I tested with subt and the levels seem to get loaded and unloaded fine.

I also tried inserting and removing objects using service calls but rewinding does not undo insertion / deletion. Maybe something for later.

content.raw: Oh yeah I forgot to mention on the summary above that insertion / deletion will need more work to playback.
content.html: Oh yeah I forgot to mention on the summary above that insertion / deletion will need more work to playback.

content.raw: Gotcha. [This commit](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/commits/e36ffc6583a9ab6069074eab19cf2917236cd161?at=ign-cmake2) makes `make codecheck` return failure if there are cppcheck warnings.
content.html: Gotcha. This commit makes make codecheck return failure if there are cppcheck warnings.

content.raw: yeah, I meant to say I prefer we address the error code before fixing the errors. Thinking further, I'll step back from saying which thing should be done first and just say that I don't think that ign-cmake change is blocking this PR unless we make changes to the `make codecheck` return code
content.html: yeah, I meant to say I prefer we address the error code before fixing the errors. Thinking further, I'll step back from saying which thing should be done first and just say that I don't think that ign-cmake change is blocking this PR unless we make changes to the make codecheck return code

content.raw:
> I would prefer that we address that before trying to fix them

I'm not sure what you're referring to, what's `that` and `them`?

If you're referring to the ign-cmake PR removing headers, I think that's the correct thing to do regardless of what error codes `make codecheck` is returning.
content.html:
I would prefer that we address that before trying to fix them

I'm not sure what you're referring to, what's that and them?

If you're referring to the ign-cmake PR removing headers, I think that's the correct thing to do regardless of what error codes make codecheck is returning.

content.raw:
if `make codecheck` doesn't return a failing code, it adds too much overhead to treat it as a failure

I would prefer that we address that before trying to fix them
content.html:
if make codecheck doesn't return a failing code, it adds too much overhead to treat it as a failure

I would prefer that we address that before trying to fix them

certain errors will cause it to return a failure code; others are just informational I guess?

if make codecheck could generate junit files, then we would see the same thing in jenkins as in the pipeline:

  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/issues/31/generate-junit-xml-from-make-codecheck

content.raw:
It doesn't  fail pipelines but it prints warnings:

~~~
[/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/src/SimulationRunner.hh:71]: (style) struct member 'WorldControl::pause' is never used.
[/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/src/SimulationRunner.hh:74]: (style) struct member 'WorldControl::multiStep' is never used.
[/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/src/SimulationRunner.hh:78]: (style) struct member 'WorldControl::rewind' is never used.
~~~

It's probably not returning a failure code.
content.html:
It doesn't fail pipelines but it prints warnings:

[/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/src/SimulationRunner.hh:71]: (style) struct member 'WorldControl::pause' is never used.
[/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/src/SimulationRunner.hh:74]: (style) struct member 'WorldControl::multiStep' is never used.
[/opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/src/SimulationRunner.hh:78]: (style) struct member 'WorldControl::rewind' is never used.

It's probably not returning a failure code.

content.raw: `make codecheck` is passing in the pipeline, does `code_check.sh` fail?
content.html: make codecheck is passing in the pipeline, does code_check.sh fail?

![log_control.gif](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3945315640-log_control.gif)

* Seeking used to also update the iteration number. Now it resets iterations to zero.

* There's nothing preventing users from rewinding and seeking during regular simulation mode. I've added warnings to all the systems which I thought could be affected by jumps back in time. Jumping forward has no warning, and systems just treat it as a really large time step. The idea is that we can implement rewind and seek for these systems in the future, and we don't want to prevent users from supporting this on their systems.

To detect pause:

To detect time jump while paused (`dt` is zero during regular pause):
